author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: The Photograph That Started a Romance
description: Najee Fortè knew he had to meet Danielle Dorsi after a mutual friend sent him a picture of her.
content: When a mutual friend sent a picture of Danielle Dorsi to Najee Fortè, it left Mr. Fortè speechless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Barbados Elects Its First Head of State, Replacing Queen Elizabeth
description: The country’s Parliament chose Sandra Mason, the governor general, to assume the symbolic title, a decisive move to distance itself from Barbados’s colonial past.
content: The island nation of Barbados has elected a female former jurist to become its next head of state, a symbolic position held since the 1950s by Queen Elizabeth II, as the country takes another step toward casting off its colonial past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Searching for Australia’s Climate Tipping Point
description: The world, and most Australians, are increasingly disappointed by Australia’s lackluster approach to addressing climate change.
content: One of the first stories I wrote when I got to Australia focused on climate change and its damaging impact on the Great Barrier Reef. Four years later, the consequences of a warming planet have only become more visible, with fires, droughts and extreme storms, but Australia’s policy settings have not shifted to match the urgency of the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Is China in Big Trouble?
description: Doomsayers have been wrong before, but this time may be different.
content: These are scary times in America, with one of our major parties careening into authoritarianism and the other having difficulty moving forward thanks to two uncooperative senators. Most of what I write, inevitably, focuses on the troubled prospects for our republic. But everyone needs a break. So today I want to talk about a happier topic: The risks of an economic crisis in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: How the Supply Chain Broke, and Why It Won’t Be Fixed Anytime Soon
description: Confession: We didn’t even have a logistics beat before the pandemic. Now we do. Here’s what we’ve learned about the global supply chain disruption.
content: Computer chips. Exercise equipment. Breakfast cereal. By now, you’ve probably heard: The world has run short of a great many products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: High Above the Newsroom, a History of The Times
description: The newly opened Museum at The Times, on the 15th floor of the Times Building in New York, is filled with curios and artifacts that date back 170 years.
content: On the 15th floor of The New York Times Building, near a newspaper that traveled close to 1.8 million miles aboard the space shuttle Columbia, is a slab of metal shaped as the letter “S.” It is a piece from the “zipper,” a belt of 14,800 bulbs that The New York Times operated to send news bulletins around Times Square, beginning in 1928.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Ron Washington Has Atlanta Laughing (While It Learns)
description: A coach’s loving and lively relationship with the Braves’ infielders is a key to their success. He’s holding out hope for a second chance to manage.
content: ATLANTA — The phone buzzed with a FaceTime request and the old coach grinned. He tapped the screen and up popped the face of his star second baseman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Bruce Springsteen, Paul McCartney and Alicia Keys Fight Poverty
description: Benefits were also held for God’s Love We Deliver and the Frick Collection.
content: Robin Hood, the big kahuna of charity dinners, raised $77.5 million to fight poverty in New York City; the Oct. 20 gala drew 2,400 people to the Javits Center, including Wall Street titans, celebrities, politicians and philanthropists. God’s Love We Deliver, which provides meals to New Yorkers living with severe or chronic illness, honored Don Lemon and Billy Porter at its annual dinner on Oct. 18 at the Glasshouse. Also on Oct, 18, the Frick Collection honored Ronald S. Lauder at its autumn dinner at the Metropolitan Club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Chinese Pianist Is Held on Prostitution Suspicion, State Media Says
description: Li Yundi, a famous performer, was accused of soliciting a woman, state news outlets said. Officials often use such accusations against their enemies.
content: A prominent Chinese pianist, Li Yundi, has been detained on prostitution suspicion in Beijing, state-run news outlets in China reported on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Chad Kimball Sues ‘Come From Away’ Over His Termination
description: The actor, who is Christian, said in an interview he was let go because of his religious beliefs. The show’s producers declined to comment.
content: A former lead actor in the musical “Come From Away” has sued the show’s producers, claiming that he was let go from the production because of his Christian beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY —  Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Health Care Employment Is Rising. Is That a Good Thing?
description: The 10 U.S. counties that depend most on this economic sector tell a complicated story.
content: There are places in America where factories have closed, mines have shut and farms have reverted to forest but hospitals and clinics are continuing to open. Health care services in such places perform two vital functions: not just caring for the sick and old but also supplying much-needed jobs. Case in point: Breathitt County in the coal fields of eastern Kentucky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater
title: House Ethics Committee Details Accusations Against 4 Lawmakers
description: The separate reports, investigating three Republicans and a Democrat, center on stock trades, the misuse of campaign funds and the improper awarding of contracts.
content: WASHINGTON — The House Committee on Ethics on Thursday released four reports into separate violations of ethics rules by four congressmen, portraying what investigators suggested was a sweeping array of improper financial conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Trump to Twitter: I Can’t Make You Love Me
description: The former president will attempt to build his own version of the social media giant.
content: Since he was tossed by Twitter, Facebook and YouTube, a part of Google, in the wake of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Donald Trump has had such a tough time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Why New York City Is Trying to Preserve a Crumbling Church
description: Grace Congregational Church wants to stay afloat by redeveloping its building, but a new historic district aimed at protecting Black culture now stands in its way.
content: Grace Congregational Church does not have many members these days, but the dozen or so people who do worship at the century-old building on a quiet Harlem side street like to get there early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Floyd Abrams
title: The Supreme Court Faces a Huge Test on Libel Law
description: Two of the justices want to revisit a landmark decision for free expression. They may soon get the chance.
content: Next Friday, the United States Supreme Court is scheduled to meet to consider whether to hear appeals from two libel cases in which the plaintiffs seek to persuade the justices to reconsider the single greatest First Amendment victory for the press in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: How Rare Is a Three-Homer Game in the Postseason?
description: Babe Ruth. Reggie Jackson. Chris Taylor? A feat that used to come few and far between is happening more often. But it is still unusual enough to stand out.
content: Chris Taylor helped the Los Angeles Dodgers stay alive in the National League Championship Series on Thursday night by belting three home runs. In the sport’s long history, three-homer games in the postseason stand out as a rarity: They have occurred only 12 times. While Taylor has had his share of postseason magic in the past, and he is a useful player, the fraternity he joined includes several all-time greats.
source.name: The New York Times

title: One Factory and the Bigger Story It Tells
description: Farah Stockman talks about “American Made,” and Benjamín Labatut discusses “When We Cease to Understand the World.”
content: In “American Made,” Farah Stockman writes about the downfall of manufacturing employment in the United States by focusing on the lives of workers at one Indianapolis factory that was relocated to Mexico. Stockman, a member of The New York Times editorial board, talks about the book on this week’s podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Monika Pronczuk
title: Poland’s Attacks on Rule of Law Leave Europe at Odds With Itself
description: E.U. leaders are facing an increasingly urgent question: What to do with a member that repeatedly violates a core principle, but refuses to leave the club?
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union is facing a growing challenge from Poland that is pitting its own institutions against each other and leaving member states divided: What to do when a member repeatedly violates rules agreed on by the bloc’s 27 countries, but shows no intention of leaving?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: The First Apartment That the Actor Anthony Rapp Bought Is for Sale
description: The actor’s success in “Rent” on Broadway allowed him to buy the NoHo studio loft, at 1 Bond Street, 23 years ago for $375,000. It is now listed for $1.95 million.
content: Long before the actor Anthony Rapp found success on Broadway in “Rent,” he was living much the same way as the struggling East Village artists the hit musical portrayed. The thought of owning a place in Manhattan at the time seemed unrealistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Tom Morey, Surfer Who Invented the Boogie Board, Dies at 86
description: He created a lightweight, flexible board out of a piece of foam in his backyard in Hawaii in 1971. It introduced millions to the pleasures of riding waves on their bellies.
content: Tom Morey, whose creation of the small, flexible, lightweight Boogie Board introduced millions to the exquisite sensation of riding waves on their bellies instead of having to balance themselves upright atop bigger, heavier surfboards, died on Oct. 14 in a hospital in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: U.S. pharmacies and states face new challenges as an expanded booster rollout begins.
description: Tens of millions of Americans have the green light to seek out the extra shots.
content: Now that federal regulators have cleared booster shots of all three coronavirus vaccines in use in the United States, state health authorities and pharmacies have begun rolling out plans to get even more shots in arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Maria Varenikova
title: A Cinematographer Killed on Set Is Recalled as Talented and Spirited
description: Halyna Hutchins, the director of photography for the film “Rust,” was killed when the actor Alec Baldwin discharged a firearm being used as a prop.
content: Shortly before the cinematographer Halyna Hutchins was fatally shot on a film set in the foothills of New Mexico, she smiled at the camera as she recorded herself riding a chestnut horse through the desert brush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Evergrande makes a payment before a default deadline, state media says.
description: The troubled real estate giant faced the threat of default if it didn’t meet its obligations to foreign bondholders by Saturday.
content: HONG KONG — China Evergrande, the troubled property giant that is teetering on the edge of collapse, appears to have bought itself a little more time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon never flop, never bluff, never lose.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage concerns a pursuit that can encapsulate all of life, if you think about it and take a moment to look through the lens of its author, Maria Konnikova. Ms. Konnikova’s path to her book, “The Biggest Bluff: How I Learned to Pay Attention, Master Myself, and Win,” is wild: A writer with a Ph.D. in psychology enters the world of high-stakes poker and immediately excels at it, noting lessons about luck versus self-determination along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Bye, Maryland? Lawmakers in 3 Counties Float a Plan to Secede From the State.
description: The proposal to join West Virginia seems destined to go nowhere. But it has tapped into deep-seated feelings of alienation in western Maryland, a mountainous panhandle wedged against the Mason-Dixon line.
content: More than 150 years after Maryland stuck with the Union, the state is facing a peculiar request by its three westernmost counties to secede.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Miriam Jordan
title: Illegal Border Crossings, Driven by Pandemic and Natural Disasters, Soar to Record High
description: Migrants were encountered 1.7 million times in the last 12 months, the highest number of illegal crossings recorded since at least 1960.
content: A record 1.7 million migrants from around the world, many of them fleeing pandemic-ravaged countries, were encountered trying to enter the United States illegally in the last 12 months, capping a year of chaos at the southern border, which has emerged as one of the most formidable challenges for the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Julia Jacobs and Glenn Thrush
title: Alec Baldwin Was Told Gun in Fatal Shooting on Set Was Safe, Officials Say
description: The actor was told a gun being used as a prop was safe before he fired it on the set of “Rust,” killing the film’s cinematographer and wounding its director, law enforcement officials said.
content: SANTA FE — On a ranch in northern New Mexico, where the cottonwoods and the dusty foothills have formed the backdrop of Westerns since the 1950s, Alec Baldwin was filming a new movie on Thursday afternoon when his character, an outlaw, needed a gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Online Furor Over a Student’s Hijab Engulfs a Liberal Town
description: A 7-year-old told her mother that she resisted a New Jersey teacher’s attempt to pull off her Muslim head covering. It spiraled from there.
content: MAPLEWOOD, N.J. — A 7-year-old girl came home from school earlier this month upset, impatient to tell her mother a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Sinema’s Blockade on Tax Rates Prods Democrats Toward Billionaires’ Tax
description: Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s refusal to raise rates on high earners and major corporations has led Democrats to consider proposals once championed only by the party’s most liberal flank.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Kyrsten Sinema, Democrat of Arizona and one of her party’s only holdouts on President Biden’s sprawling budget bill, has cultivated a profile in Congress as a business-minded centrist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Emerging Through the Fog of a Pandemic With ‘Giselle’
description: American Ballet Theater returns to Lincoln Center with its full-length production — and with it, a breakthrough performance by Skylar Brandt.
content: Back in September of 2020, when performances in most New York City theaters were very much on pause, American Ballet Theater announced a slew of promotions for dancers with great fanfare. It was an odd move given the time and the state of the world: Was it a way to tell dancers (and donors) something along the lines of keep the faith — but also keep working out?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Afia Atakora
title: For Tiphanie Yanique, Black Love Comes With Baggage
description: In “Monster in the Middle,” parents beget children who inherit their pain, their care and their madness.
content: MONSTER IN THE MIDDLE By Tiphanie Yanique
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Ringelheim
title: Two Wrongs Don’t Make Mr. Right
description: He wanted to get really serious really fast, which felt good until it didn’t.
content: When my Hinge match said on our first date that he wanted a serious relationship, a house with a fence, and children soon, I thought, “Maybe I should introduce him to Zerrin.” She, my dear friend, wanted something like that, too. I could not know that later that same night, in a city of eight million, Zerrin had a first date scheduled with the same man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: How Would You Describe Your Pandemic Experience in Six Words?
description: Have you ever written a six-word memoir? This is an invitation to create a special one about the last 19 months.
content: Have you ever heard of the six-word memoir, or had to write one in school? If not, here is how Larry Smith, the creator, explains them:

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Biden Bolsters Filibuster Foes, but a Fight May Wait for a Budget Deal
description: The president’s criticism of the Senate tactic was a recognition that legislating has become nearly impossible when the filibuster is routine.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s endorsement on Thursday of substantially overhauling the filibuster was the clearest recognition yet that the Senate’s signature procedural weapon has rendered the polarized chamber a legislative wasteland, and that Democrats plan to try to do something about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: The Market for Single-Family Rentals Grows as Homeownership Wanes
description: House hunters are attracted to the hassle-free living and lack of down payments, but there’s a trade-off: They give up the investment of owning a home.
content: The lawns are manicured. The swimming pools sparkle in the sun. And the homes, all of them turnkey and smelling of fresh paint, are lined up in tidy rows, an army of cookie-cutter porches standing at attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: The 31st Date Was a Charm
description: Gabi Conti’s romantic losing streak was broken when she met Daren Johnson — and gave him a much-needed attitude adjustment.
content: If Gabi Conti learned anything from the exercise in extreme dating she undertook as a writer for Cosmopolitan magazine in 2019, it was to cut through the pleasantries. So when Daren Johnson, whom she met on Bumble that year, failed to live up to her expectations about how a person should conduct himself on a first date, she didn’t hesitate to tell him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Lines Blur Between Government and Gangs Terrorizing Haitians
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 22, 2021.
content: “The gangs have more authority than our leaders. If they say, ‘Stay home,’ you stay home. If they say, ‘Go out,’ you can go out. It’s terror.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Cuddling Once a Day. That Is Their Rule.
description: Anne Dimock and Richard Olver were living on different coasts and had four divorces between them when they met online in 2017.
content: Ann Dimock and Richard Olver first met in February 2017 through Stitch.net, a relationship and community-building site with an office in the San Francisco Bay Area. Ms. Dimock had reached out to Mr. Olver, who was all the way across the country in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. “Too bad we live far apart,” her message to him read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Managing A.D.H.D. Is Hard. These Coaches Want to Help.
description: A growing crop of professionals are guiding people with attention deficit disorder toward healthier behaviors, and self-acceptance.
content: Weekday mornings have become “drive-to-school jam out time” for Dan and Melissa Roberts, and their four boys. The couple, who live near Grand Rapids, Mich., let each son take turns picking the music. (Imagine Dragons, Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith are current favorites.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Erin Griffith
title: Key takeaways from Week 7 of the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
description: Prosecutors focused on her alleged deceptions, trying to make the case that she intentionally misled Theranos’s investors and commercial partners.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — In the seventh week of the fraud trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood-testing start-up Theranos, testimony moved away from science and into discussions of faked demonstrations and misleading marketing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: No Longer Boxed In, Volvo Wins Over Buyers With Its Sleeker Look
description: With an aggressive push for electric vehicles and a coming I.P.O., the century-old Swedish carmaker is positioning itself for the future.
content: Volvo is perhaps best known in America for rectilinear sedans and, especially, station wagons. This is something of a well-earned reputation. For decades, the Swedish company produced angular, sensible vehicles, which put a priority on reliability and safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: How Russia Is Cashing In on Climate Change
description: Global warming may pose grave dangers around the world, but as one tiny Russian town on the Arctic Ocean shows, it can also be a ticket to prosperity.
content: PEVEK, Russia — A refurbished port. A spanking new plant to generate electricity. Repaved roads. And money left over to repair the library and put in a new esplanade along the shore of the Arctic Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
title: Bali reopens to foreign tourists, but government rules keep them away.
description: Not a single international flight carrying tourists has landed in Bali, one of the world’s most popular destinations, and none are scheduled, even though Indonesia announced more than a week ago that the popular island was finally open again for tourists.
content: Not a single international flight carrying tourists has landed in Bali, one of the world’s most popular destinations, and none are scheduled, even though Indonesia announced more than a week ago that the popular island was finally open again for tourists.

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: After Dropping Free Community College Plan, Democrats Explore Options
description: Expanded tuition assistance remains an option for the budget bill, but how much it would help students — and economic competitiveness — remains to be seen.
content: WASHINGTON — On the campaign trail, Joseph R. Biden Jr. heavily promoted his plan to offer tuition-free community college. He pitched the proposal as crucial to his economic agenda — a way to rebuild the middle class, which he called the “backbone” of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester United’s Perfect Feedback Loop
description: Title contender, crisis club or cash cow? What you see in United depends, largely, on what you want to see.
content: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was in the mood to play the hits. Manchester United’s most ardent fans, he said, were “the best in the world.” The players who had the privilege to wear the team’s colors were the “luckiest” on the planet. And, of course, there was the inevitable nod to history, to the club’s “habit” of clawing victory from the maw of defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and David Kasnic
title: To Get Ahead at Work, Lawyers Find It Helps to Actually Be at Work
description: The generational divide on returning to the office is not neatly drawn. For some young professionals, even in a pandemic, showing up is more than half the battle.
content: It looked like a middle-aged person’s idea of what a young person would find fun. There was a dartboard on the wall, a pool table to the side and a Blue Bunny ice cream cart near the entrance, tended to by representatives from H.R.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Alberta Took on Environmental Groups, but Only Proved They Did Nothing Wrong
description: The report from a provincial inquiry into “anti-Alberta energy campaigns” didn’t back up Premier Jason Kenney’s allegations.
content: When Alberta released its report into foreign influence of environmental groups on Thursday, Jason Kenney, the premier, was conspicuously absent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Warns of Efforts by China to Collect Genetic Data
description: The National Counterintelligence and Security Center said American companies needed to better secure critical technologies as Beijing seeks to dominate the so-called bioeconomy.
content: BETHESDA, Md. — Chinese firms are collecting genetic data from around the world, part of an effort by the Chinese government and companies to develop the world’s largest bio-database, American intelligence officials reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: This Hedge Fund Manager Dumped Trump
description: The investor Boaz Weinstein moved to abandon a blank-check fund that announced a deal with the former president.
content: News that Donald Trump was bankrolling a new media venture through a SPAC deal sent shares in the blank-check fund soaring some 350 percent. Much of that probably came from individual fans of the former president plowing into the vehicle, Digital World Acquisition. But at least one of the SPAC’s backers, a major hedge fund, pulled out over the Trump connection, and the question now is whether others will follow suit — or chase potential profit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: TV Shows Filmed in L.A. Are Finally Starting to Look Familiar
description: On the small screen, Los Angeles is home to more than just the rich and famous.
content: If you’ve spent much time in Los Angeles, you’ve probably at some point been watching TV and realized, “Hey, I know that place!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Matthew Phillips
title: The Fed chair strikes a wary tone on inflation, but says this isn’t the time to raise interest rates.
description: Jerome H. Powell said that it was important for policy to be positioned to react, and that the Federal Reserve would act to keep prices stable if necessary.
content: The pandemic-related shortages pushing consumer prices higher are poised to last longer than economists and policymakers expected, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said on Friday — adding that while officials still expect the rate of inflation to moderate, the central bank is positioning itself to react if it does not.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Original Black Media King
description: Byron Lewis knew there was an untapped market for Black storytelling. But it took years for the rest of the country to believe him.
content: In the late 1950s, long before he would be appreciated as one of the country’s most prominent Black media executives, Byron Lewis had a job working the weekend shift on the classified pages of The New York Times. Mr. Lewis had graduated from Long Island University in 1953, where he studied journalism before joining the Army. The fact that he was a Black man in the middle of the 20th century gave him little hope that he would land a job as a reporter, so he set his sights on something in advertising or publishing with the goal of earning $100 a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The Big Quit.
content: At first, everyone tried to make the best of a bad situation: gathering on Zoom, launching projects in the kitchen and cheering on health care workers, and ourselves, with daily quarantine clapping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: An Espionage Opera Remains Enigmatic and Urgent
description: Robert Ashley’s “eL/Aficionado” is receiving a rare revival that is a testament to its vitality.
content: You can’t help but feel some sympathy for the protagonist of Robert Ashley’s opera “eL/Aficionado” when she says, “The meaning of the scene is impossible to describe, if one looks for meaning in the ordinary sense.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles V. Bagli
title: Robert Durst Charged With Murder in 1982 Disappearance of His Wife
description: Mr. Durst was recently convicted of murdering a friend because of what she knew about his wife’s disappearance from their Lewisboro, N.Y., home.
content: When Kathie McCormack Durst, the young wife of a Manhattan real estate heir, vanished from her Westchester County, N.Y., home on a cold, rainy night in 1982, she left an enduring mystery that has tormented her family and friends and fascinated investigators and the public ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Shulevitz
title: Is This the Cure for the Loneliness of American Motherhood?
description: American moms are isolated, overworked and undersupported. The solution may be living together, separately.
content: Eastern Village, a 55-unit apartment complex off a commercial strip in Silver Spring, Md., is a surprisingly lovely place, considering that it once housed the drab offices of a social workers’ association and then stood abandoned for nearly a decade, water dripping through the ceilings. When I visited this summer, ivy cascaded so exuberantly over the facade that I walked past the entrance. The landscaped courtyard, wrested out of a parking lot, exuded European charm. Looking up, I saw open walkways lined with balconies, flowers and herbs. Then I spotted a baldish man sitting at a little round table waving to me. He had to be Rabbi Jason Kimelman-Block, a friend of a friend I had asked to show me around the place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Daniel Guillemette, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Jessica Cheung, Rachelle Bonja, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Qaddafi's Son Is Alive, and He Wants to Take Back Libya
description: In the decade since Libya’s dictator Muammar el-Qaddafi was overthrown, the country has devolved into chaos. Now, his son is plotting a political comeback.
content: Before the Arab Spring, Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the second son of the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was establishing himself as a serious figure internationally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: How to Protect Yourself From Online Card Fraud
description: The first tip is to use credit cards for digital shopping because they have federally mandated protections. And be wary of websites that offer brand-name goods at steep discounts.
content: Americans are expected to do much of their holiday shopping online this year even as the pandemic recedes, and criminals are expected to follow them. So here are some tips for safe digital shopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Why Is Everyone Else Quitting?
description: Sometimes, as in a collective bargaining situation, you do have to think about other people at work. Other times, it’s better to focus on what you really want.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Amanda Knox Was Exonerated. That Doesn’t Mean She’s Free.
description: Ten years after being cleared of a heinous crime, she is still trying to tell her story on her own terms.
content: VASHON, Wash. — Within minutes of meeting Amanda Knox for the first time, she planted her newborn daughter into my arms. Yes, Amanda Knox has a baby. A baby that she has been keeping a secret for months, worried that photographers would show up at her door, worried it would become a headline about “Foxy Knoxy’s path to motherhood,” which of course now it will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Forgoing the Cheese Plate to Forge a Connection
description: When Jarrett Olivo walked into a party, Brian Ellner made a ‘rare’ move away from the cheese board to introduce himself.
content: Brian Ellner was appraising the cheese spread at a party in Bellport, N.Y., in April 2018, when Jarrett Olivo walked through the door. Mr. Ellner said he practically leapt over the couch to say hello.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Jonathan Abrams
title: What the Ben Simmons Standoff Means for the Sixers and the N.B.A.
description: Simmons is the latest N.B.A. star to ask for a trade then try to force his way off a team, but Philadelphia is holding firm so far.
content: Over the summer, Philadelphia 76ers guard Ben Simmons requested a trade, initiating a standoff that has dragged into the regular season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: In ‘An Evening of Hope,’ a Veteran Dancer Gets Personal
description: A program of works by the former Alvin Ailey member Hope Boykin is about stepping into a surer sense of herself.
content: In a company like Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, where the celebrated Hope Boykin performed for 20 years, dancers are more often seen than heard onstage. Having retired from that company last year, and now devoting herself more fully to her own work, Boykin is making her voice heard. Not just her choreographic voice, or what she calls “my movement language,” but spoken language, too: inner dialogues turned outward for us to hear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Constant Méheut
title: ‘Morally, They Are Lost’: Gangs in Haiti, Breaking a Taboo, Target the Church
description: A French priest in Haiti recalls his kidnapping by 400 Mawozo, the same gang holding 16 Americans and a Canadian, including children, for ransom.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The gang kept them for 19 days, giving the captives nearly everything they asked for: soap, decent food and even Gatorade. But as time wore on, the gang grew more nervous, ripping apart the priests’ gowns to make blindfolds and handcuffs. When they feared the ransom would not be paid, they withheld food as a pressure tactic to speed up payment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: In ‘Unedited,’ the Revisions Are Part of the Tradition
description: Risk and improvisation are integral to kathak, the Indian classical dance form on display in Rachna Nivas’s stunning solo performance at Dixon Place.
content: For a dancer to explain, mid-show, that she has never before performed with her accompanying musicians — and that they have barely rehearsed — might seem like an excuse or an apology for roughness. But in her solo performance at Dixon Place on Thursday, Rachna Nivas said those words with pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Even With a Dream Job, You Can Be Antiwork
description: The pandemic has prompted a dawning realization that we are way too obsessed with our jobs.
content: The world’s long-suffering workers have finally gained some measure of leverage over their bosses, and their new power is a glorious thing to behold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: An Arctic Dispatch
description: We visit a Russian town on the Arctic Ocean that sees climate change as an economic opportunity.
content: Climate-change adaptation can be a difficult subject to discuss. Thinking about how society will adjust to the consequences of climate change seems to smack of defeatism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Her (Lack of) Kickball Skills Made Him Know She Was a Keeper
description: Benjamin Allen and Courtney Thomas bonded over a shared ability to embrace life’s awkward moments.
content: When Benjamin Allen met Courtney Thomas on a kickball field in Harrisburg, Pa., in August 2015, he said it was her lack of skill that attracted him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Clouds
description: What do you think this image is saying?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Klay Thompson Finally Found Love. With His Boat.
description: Injury woes sent Thompson, the Golden State guard, looking for solace. He found it on the water. No bananas allowed.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Klay Thompson commutes to work in a 37-foot fishing boat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Said the U.S. Would Protect Taiwan. But It’s Not That Clear-Cut.
description: After the president’s remarks at a CNN event, the White House quickly declared that the American policy of “strategic ambiguity” over the island’s defense had not changed.
content: WASHINGTON — American presidents have spent decades trying to sidestep the question of how forcefully the United States would come to the aid of Taiwan if China invaded it or, more likely, tried to slowly strangle the island in an effort to force it back under the control of the mainland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: In the Company of Wes Anderson
description: What is it about the director that draws stars like Frances McDormand and Tilda Swinton again and again? There are many reasons, but the nightly feasts don’t hurt.
content: It’s his first film set in France, and the first done as an anthology. But Wes Anderson’s 10th movie, “The French Dispatch,” was made in much the same way, and with much the same cast, as many of the features that preceded it. Along with his fastidious and vibrant visual sense and staccato pacing, his company of free spirits has become his signature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: One-Fourth of KISS
description: Robyn Weintraub turns our T.G.I.F. into T.G.I.W.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It is always a pleasure to open a puzzle and see Robyn Weintraub’s byline. She sets such a high bar for herself and, by extension, for other constructors. Her puzzles contain little to no junk, lots of terrific entries and very clever cluing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: America Was Forged by the Marginalized
description: How the political struggles waged by Black Americans forged U.S. democracy — and what we can learn from them.
content: In the wake of the “Stop the Steal” campaign, the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol and the wave of voter suppression bills making their way through Republican legislatures across the country, the struggle for American democracy feels, for many, visceral and even existential. But for Martha S. Jones, a legal and cultural historian at Johns Hopkins University, the moment we find ourselves in is anything but an aberration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Again Refuses to Block Texas Abortion Law
description: But the court said it would hear arguments on Nov. 1 on challenges to the law from the Biden administration and abortion providers in the state.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday once again refused to immediately block a Texas law that bans most abortions after six weeks. But in an unusual move, the justices agreed to fast-track their consideration of appeals from the Justice Department and abortion providers in Texas, scheduling arguments for Nov. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone and Declan Walsh
title: U.N. Flight Thwarted as Fighting Grows in Ethiopia
description: A humanitarian flight was ordered to abort a landing in the capital of Ethiopia’s Tigray region, epicenter of the conflict, as government airstrikes hit the area for a fourth day.
content: A United Nations humanitarian flight to the Ethiopian region of Tigray, epicenter of a year-old war that threatens to cause deepening famine, was ordered to abort a landing on Friday as government airstrikes hit the area for a fourth day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By E. Tammy Kim and Damon Winter
title: They Are a Tribe of ‘Salmon People.’ Can They Pull Off One More Big Win?
description: The Lummi Nation has a long, proud history of contesting ecologically unfriendly projects. Will it succeed against yet another threat?
content: One afternoon this August, I boarded the Salish Sea, a crabbing boat named after the inland ocean that gives the Washington State coastline its defining divot. Dana Culaxten Wilson, one of the most prolific fishers in the Lummi Nation, and his crew of two were on their final outing of a 30-hour “crab opening,” a period approved for tribal commercial crabbing. That morning, they had dropped another round of 30 baited pots; now they rushed to locate and haul them up one last time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Predicts Trump Will Post Dares on Truth Social
description: Noah did an impression of Trump posting on his new social media site: “OK, I shared my truth, now I dare you to hang Mike Pence.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Melbourne, after 262 days in lockdown, celebrates a reopening.
description: After hitting a vaccination target, Australia’s second largest city now has many fewer restrictions.
content: The residents of Melbourne have spent more days in lockdown — 262, to be precise — than people anywhere else in the world. And on Friday, they emerged from it with cheers, and a dose of caution, as restrictions began to ease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A ‘Royal’ Wedding in Brooklyn
description: Princess Francois and Andy Estevez, both educators, had each resigned themselves to romantic disappointment — until they met four years ago.
content: Until he met Princess Francois, Andy Estevez felt like the king of lonely hearts. “Put it this way: I was a dork, dork, dork,” he said. “I was completely focused on being the best student when I was growing up and then completely focused on being the best professional as an adult.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Inside the World of Buy Nothing, Where Dryer Lint Is a Hot Commodity
description: From medical supplies to half-eaten birthday cakes, Buy Nothing is fostering a quirky sense of community that is mostly fun and occasionally irritating.
content: David Stahl did not need leftover pickle juice because, really, no one needs someone else’s used brine. But a few months ago, he decided to ask for some just to see if it was possible, posting a request to an Upper West Side chapter of Buy Nothing, a hyperlocal Facebook group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How Humans Lost Their Tails’
description: In this lesson students will learn why monkeys have tails, while apes and humans don’t — and imagine what life would be like if we had kept ours.
content: Featured Article: “How Humans Lost Their Tails” by Carl Zimmer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dorothy Steel, Whose Big-Screen Career Had a Late Start, Dies at 95
description: She was cast in “Black Panther” at 90, not long after she began acting professionally. “As soon as we saw her,” the movie’s casting director said, “we wanted her.”
content: Dorothy Steel was 90 and had been acting professionally for little more than a year when her agent asked her, in late 2016, if she wanted to audition for a role in “Black Panther,” the Marvel Studios film set in the fantastical African nation of Wakanda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Who Will Save Alice’s Tea Cup?
description: The famous teahouse is celebrating its 20th anniversary. But its owners, exhausted from the pandemic, are exploring selling the family business.
content: The vibe at Alice’s Tea Cup, the whimsical teahouse on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, was a busy mellow on a recent Sunday afternoon. People stood around, casually waiting to be seated, while the restaurant’s outdoor tables — overflowing with fancy teapots and three-tiered trays full of scones, salmon and cucumber sandwiches, cookies and slices of chocolate layer cake — bustled with customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: ‘Rust’ is about a teenager who goes on the run after accidentally killing someone.
description: The movie was inspired by a story about the youngest person ever hanged in the American West, Alec Baldwin has said.
content: “Rust” is a western set in Kansas in the 1880s, about a 13-year-old boy who goes on the run with his estranged grandfather — a notorious outlaw named Harland Rust, played by Alec Baldwin — after the boy accidentally kills a local rancher. The movie, which was scheduled to be filmed this month and next month in New Mexico, is being directed by Joel Souza and stars Frances Fisher and Mr. Baldwin, who is also listed as one of several producers of the film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: A Love as Old as AOL Instant Messenger
description: Gillian Stoss and Zach Lent dated for 16 years — more than half of their lives — before taking their relationship to the next level.
content: Gillian Stoss first spotted Zach Lent 16 years ago at a basketball championship. The team from her elementary school, St. Brendan Parish School in San Francisco, was competing against Mr. Lent’s team from the city’s Star of the Sea School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Congressional Leaders Ask N.F.L. for Documents From Washington Team Inquiry
description: The requests from two House Democrats could lead to public disclosure of more of the 650,000 emails gathered in the league’s investigation of the Washington Football Team’s workplace culture.
content: Two members of Congress have asked the N.F.L. for documents related to the league’s investigation of widespread harassment and misconduct within the Washington Football Team, raising the possibility that more of the 650,000 emails captured in that inquiry may be disclosed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: What to Do With All Those Apples
description: Did you bring home a ton from the orchard, too? Here’s how to use them.
content: I went apple picking last weekend, along with about a million other people in the New York metro area. Is it me, or does recreational apple picking just continue to surge year over year as a fall activity? Some people are not into it, which I get, and yes, cynically speaking, it’s an excellent flannel-clad Instagram moment. But I’ve done it for years, and, for my small kids who live nowhere near a farm, it’s a very clear moment of connection: Fruit comes from trees!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: He’s Bobby V, and He Wants to Be Mayor
description: The mayor’s race in Stamford has been flooded with money and intrigue, thanks largely to the flamboyant presence of Bobby Valentine, a first-time candidate and former Mets and Red Sox manager.
content: In Stamford, the second-largest city in Connecticut, a province of mixed baseball loyalties lying between New York and Boston, one of the last remaining names on the ballot for mayor this fall is more familiar to sports fans than to municipal policy wonks: Bobby Valentine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britain opened up with hardly any restrictions, a gamble now facing its toughest test.
description: For the last four months, Britain has run a grand epidemiological experiment, lifting virtually all coronavirus restrictions, even in the face of a high daily rate of infections. Its leaders justified the approach on the grounds that the country’s rapid rollout of vaccines had weakened the link between infection and serious illness.
content: For the last four months, Britain has run a grand epidemiological experiment, lifting virtually all coronavirus restrictions, even in the face of a high daily rate of infections. Its leaders justified the approach on the grounds that the country’s rapid rollout of vaccines had weakened the link between infection and serious illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Joel Souza, ‘Rust’ director, is released from the hospital after being shot on set.
description: Mr. Souza has been a writer or director on six low-budget independent films over the past decade.
content: Joel Souza, the director who was shot Thursday on the set of Alec Baldwin’s film “Rust,” was released from a hospital in New Mexico late Thursday and is expected to make a full recovery, according to a person with knowledge of his condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: My Boyfriend Is Ready for a Makeover. What Do I Do?
description: A reader, whose significant other is ready for a new wardrobe, asks for guidance in searching for staples for men.
content: This is like “The Princess Diaries,” but with a different gender and without the pomp and circumstance. Or maybe a real-life version of the Ryan Gosling revamp of Steve Carell in “Crazy, Stupid, Love,” only with a different starting point. We tend to focus on women when it comes to makeovers or wardrobe updates, in part because men’s wear always seems so proscribed, but there’s a long (if subtle) history in male makeovers too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Says Pfizer Vaccine’s Benefits Outweigh Key Risks in Children 5 to 11
description: The findings could add momentum for F.D.A. authorization of the pediatric dose, perhaps as early as next week, a long-awaited development that would affect 28 million children.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators evaluated for the first time on Friday the safety and efficacy of a coronavirus vaccine for children 5 to 11, saying that the benefits of staving off Covid-19 with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine generally outweighed the risks of the most worrisome possible side effects in that age group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Millions in U.S. aid benefited richer hospitals, a new study shows.
description: More federal aid flowed to hospitals that were in a strong financial position before the pandemic than went to hospitals with weaker balance sheets, researchers found.
content: A new analysis underscores concerns about how federal aid was allocated to health care institutions under the Provider Relief Fund, a $175-billion program that has drawn sharp criticism for giving so much money to the wealthiest U.S. hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: You and Me Need to Talk
description: This subject is debatable.
content: I seem to have wandered into more, as Daffy Duck once had it, “pronoun trouble.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Goldman Sachs offers big retention bonuses to top executives, a year after docking their pay.
description: The announcement came one year after Goldman admitted criminal wrongdoing by its Malaysian subsidiary for its role in the looting of 1MDB, the Malaysian government’s sovereign wealth fund.
content: A year after Goldman Sachs clawed back or cut compensation from its top bosses over a corruption scandal, it’s paying them multimillion-dollar bonuses to stick around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Coal Stocks Rise, Even as the Planet Warms
description: As the prospects for strong government action to curb climate change grow less certain, energy shares, and especially coal mining stocks, are generating astonishing returns.
content: In a world grappling with climate change, you might expect fossil fuel companies to be declining in value, and indeed, that was the prevailing picture through much of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand Wants a 90% Vaccination Rate. Its Street Gangs May Hold the Key.
description: The country’s leaders have set aside some misgivings and cooperated with gang leaders to reach their communities.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Rawiri Jansen, a Maori doctor, had an urgent message for the 150 people, mostly patch-wearing members of New Zealand’s plentiful street gangs and their families, who sat before him on a bright Saturday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Narrowing the Vaccine Racial Gap and Fighting Sneaker Bots: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Rambo, Romeo, Rome: His Posters Capture Films’ Essential Moments
description: Renato Casaro’s hand-drawn art has hooked movie audiences around the world since the 1950s. Tarantino and Stallone are big fans. One secret to his success? “You can’t cheat.”
content: TREVISO, Italy — Renato Casaro was taking a trip down memory lane, a long journey in a career that extends from the 1950s, when Rome was known as Hollywood on the Tiber, to the last decade when Quentin Tarantino asked for his help on the 2019 film “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: NASA Plans February Moon Launch With Giant Rocket
description: A flight of the Space Launch System and Orion capsule without astronauts aboard is planned for early next year, a first, long-delayed step toward returning astronauts to the moon’s surface.
content: NASA set dates on Friday for its giant rocket to launch a spacecraft to the moon and back, beginning in mid-February next year. No, for real this time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Their Chemistry Developed Organically
description: Ashley Chiang and Dr. Roy Xiao met on the first day of freshmen orientation at Princeton, but their relationship didn’t take off until sophomore year.
content: Ashley Chiang planned to go to medical school after college, and was even accepted into an early-admissions program during her sophomore year at Princeton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an Argentine psychological thriller, a charming Korean drama and an elliptical Galician war film.
content: In the age of streaming, the earth is flat — screen-size — with travel to faraway destinations only a monthly subscription and a click away. We’ve journeyed through the world of options and chosen the best new international movies for you to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: How Hans Zimmer Conjured the Otherworldly Sounds of ‘Dune’
description: The composer worked with a far-flung “band” of collaborators who sung, scraped metal, invented instruments and more for the score.
content: When the composer Hans Zimmer was approached to score “Dune,” the new movie adaptation of Frank Herbert’s epic sci-fi novel, he knew one thing absolutely: It would not sound like “Star Wars.” Musically, those films drew on influences that ranged from Holst and Stravinsky to classic movie scores of the ’30s and ’40s. Even the rollicking tune performed by the bug-eyed creatures in the Cantina was inspired by Benny Goodman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Will Libya Be Ruled by Another Qaddafi?
description: The former dictator’s son is running for office. Can he win?
content: The Daily strives to reveal a new idea in every episode. Below, we go deeper on one from our show this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Recent Accidents on TV and Movie Sets
description: Accidents on sets have resulted in numerous deaths and injuries over the years, some bringing about lawsuits or changes in safety guidelines.
content: Behind the magic of movies and television are actors and props, crew members, stunt performers and a sometimes dangerous set of circumstances for the people filming scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Flying With Your Pet? It Just Got a Lot More Difficult.
description: A recent C.D.C. rabies rule, pricey pet ‘tickets’ and limits on animals in airline cabins are making traveling with a pet more complicated.
content: Vivian Harvey, 81, goes to Guatemala every winter, where she spends five months tutoring children. And for 11 years, she has brought her dachshund, Sadie, along for the trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Jay Ellis Comes Home to Harlem
description: The “Insecure” actor goes on a walking tour of his adopted neighborhood.
content: Jay Ellis was buying snacks at a corner bodega in Harlem when a woman in a crop top and Ray-Bans approached him. “Oh my God, I’m so happy!” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Emily Cochrane
title: Biden Is Open to Scrapping Filibuster for Voting Rights Bill ‘and Maybe More’
description: The president said any push to “fundamentally alter” the Senate’s 60-vote threshold would have to wait until after Congress passed his vast spending agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Thursday that he was open to ending the Senate filibuster so Democrats could pass voting rights legislation, raise the federal debt limit and possibly enact other parts of his agenda that had been blocked by Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Names Neera Tanden as White House Staff Secretary
description: The move comes after her nomination as budget director was pulled earlier this year over her frequent caustic remarks on social media.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday named Neera Tanden, a longtime Democratic insider in Washington, to be White House staff secretary, moving her into a little-known but influential West Wing post after failing earlier this year to install her as the director of the Office of Management and Budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Instant Pot Wisdom, Half a Decade Later
description: Melissa Clark on how to get the most out of your electric pressure cooker, whether you’re just starting out with it or already an expert.
content: When I first wrote about Instant Pots back in 2017, it was with the ardor of new love. I’d fallen hard for my first electric pressure cooker, delighting in the myriad ways it could improve my kitchen life. All those weeknight meals of dried beans and silky braised meats, the speedy brown rice, the endless flow of soups and homemade stock changed how I cooked in a fundamental way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The geopolitical risks of climate change.
content: The Biden administration released several reports about the risk of climate change to national security, laying out in stark terms the ways in which the warming world is beginning to significantly challenge stability worldwide, through developments such as worsening international conflict and increased dislocation and migration as people flee climate-fueled instability.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Jamelle Bouie Interviews Martha S. Jones for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
description: A conversation with the legal historian.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Jamelle Bouie and featuring Martha S. Jones. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

author: By David Allen
title: Bernard Haitink, Perhaps the Wisest Conductor of Them All
description: The unflashy maestro, who died on Thursday, gave orchestras a sound with integrity, weight and gravity, without heaviness.
content: What I can still feel today, almost in my skin, is the warmth. It was July 20, 2009, at the Royal Albert Hall in London; I sat behind the orchestra, all the better to see the conductor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Lyft Says 1,807 Sexual Assaults Occurred in Rides in 2019
description: The company’s first-ever safety report, which it committed two years ago to producing, also included four fatal assaults and 49 deaths in crashes.
content: More than 1,800 sexual assaults occurred during Lyft rides in 2019, the company said on Thursday in its first-ever safety report on sexual and physical assaults, fatal crashes and other serious incidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: El Niño and La Niña, Explained
description: If you’re wondering why scientists and weather forecasters are talking about these phenomena, we have some answers, including how they got their names.
content: If you follow the weather — and who doesn’t? — you will hear about El Niño and La Niña from time to time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Needle Spiking’ of Women in Britain Stirs Alarm Over New Kind of Assault
description: Women are reporting being injected with syringes at crowded clubs in a horrifying variation of dropping pill into drinks. “This is a new depth,’’ said a former chief of police.
content: NOTTINGHAM, England — Lizzie Wilson was standing in a crowded nightclub on Monday night with three friends when she felt a sharp pinch in her back, as if she had been pricked by a needle. Ten minutes later, she was struggling to stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Is the New Aspirin Advice a Medical Flip-Flop, or Just Science?
description: Medical reversals about menopause hormones, knee surgery and vitamins over the years have left patients confused. But doctors say these pivots often are good medicine.
content: When it comes to preventive health, few tenets are as entrenched as daily aspirin. For more than 30 years, many people have relied on the pain reliever for added protection against a first heart attack or stroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: inadvertently
description: This word has appeared in 254 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Lev Parnas, Ex-Giuliani Ally, Is Convicted of Campaign Finance Charges
description: A federal jury found that Mr. Parnas and a second man funneled a Russian tycoon’s money to U.S. candidates to win favorable treatment for a marijuana business.
content: Lev Parnas and his business partner, Igor Fruman, had climbed to prominent places in the orbit of President Donald J. Trump when they were arrested at Dulles International Airport near Washington in 2019 while holding one-way tickets to Frankfurt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Andrew Lloyd Webber Brings the Music of the Night Back to ‘Phantom’
description: After a long pandemic pause, “The Phantom of the Opera” is returning to Broadway with some help from its creator.
content: Andrew Lloyd Webber looked pleased.

author: By Emily Schmall, Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
title: Violence Strikes, and India’s Farmers Want You to See It
description: A year on, protesters against the country’s agricultural laws are taking an increasingly confrontational approach with the country’s leaders.
content: LAKHIMPUR KHERI, India — The jeep plowed into the protesters, sending bodies tumbling, the windshield cracking against bone. The son of a prominent politician was then accused of murder. Rifle-toting security personnel flooded the area. Tempers flared so hotly that local officials shut down the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Striving for Authenticity, Films Often Use Real Guns on Set
description: Safety protocols for firearms on set are well established and straight forward, and injuries of any kind are rare.
content: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood was in a state of shock on Friday, one day after Alec Baldwin fired a gun being used as a prop on a New Mexico film set, killing a cinematographer and wounding the director. Real firearms are routinely used while cameras are rolling, and injuries of any kind are rare. The reason is that safety protocols for firearms on sets are well established and straight forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Peter Scolari, ‘Newhart’ and ‘Girls’ Actor, Is Dead at 66

title: The U.S. starts giving Covid boosters to millions, as people in poor nations await their first doses.
description: The booster program underlines the disparity in vaccine access, with wealthier nations accounting for more than three-quarters of all doses administered so far.
content: As the United States began to offer Covid booster shots to tens of millions of people, representatives of the World Health Organization continued this week to sound the alarm over the disparity in vaccine access globally, with the world’s poorest countries struggling to get even a first dose into their citizens’ arms.

title: Men Are Caregivers, Too, in Democrats’ Plan
description: Compared with its peers, the U.S. has little in the way of family policy, but where it exists, it has mostly treated men and women the same. The Democrats’ plan would cement that.
content: Pete Buttigieg faced criticism from certain conservatives for taking paternity leave with his newborn twins. But his decision to do so showed something distinct about American family policy: It may be flimsy compared with that of many other nations, but it has tended to recognize caregiving as something everyone does, not just mothers.

content: There are family members we never get to meet, those whose absences are filled by the memories of the people who knew them. I never met my great-grandmother Osunfunke Thomas (nee Olatunji), but I’ve formed an image of her from the story of her passing, as told to me by my mother and her sisters. She was 76, and it happened quite suddenly, as she was crushing aromatics for dinner on a grinding stone.
